awd_titl_txt: Measure Theory and Geometric Topology in Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of Dynamical Systems theory is to describe the long run behavior of a body or of a collection of particles subject to laws of motion.  It is often the case that full knowledge of the particles' position and velocity are not exact.  As a particle moves after a unit of time (say a day), the new position is not known exactly.  In this project such systems are studied.  The goal is to show that the long run behavior of the collection of particles is governed by some probability distribution in the phase space.  The distribution should have nice geometric properties.   While the "chaotic" behavior of these system is by definition impossible to be exactly predicted there are systems which are described by algebraic equations where researchers can probabilistically study the long run behavior.

The random iteration of diffeomorphisms is an important model for different types of dynamical systems. The PI plans to study these random iterations and gives a precise (as precise as possible) description of the stationary measure associated with it, particularly its geometric properties.   Once geometric properties are established, some statistical properties can be deduced as corollaries, for example, the equidistribution of almost every orbit with respect to volume. This project will develop in two additional directions.  One concerns dynamical systems with multidimensional time (i.e. actions of higher rank groups) and the other concerns classical dynamical systems (i.e. one dimensional time) displaying some uniform (though possibly partial) hyperbolicity. The unifying theme in the study is the techniques used which involve the interactions between measure theoretical and topological properties of a system. In all cases a description of relevant invariant measures is desired, how this impacts the topological dynamics and ultimately how this affects the topology of the ambient manifold. The PI also seeks intermediate interactions, for instance how the topology of the manifold imposes restrictions on the dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
The project ?Measure Theory and Geometric Topology in Dynamics? have concentrated in the development of tools to study the dynamics and ergodic theory of group actions through topologically geometric concepts. Group actions is a general concept that includes iterations of functions or evolution of a system of particles as well as systems with symmetries or multidimensional time. 

 

In this situation, the question of when a system preserve an invariant measure and what are the geometric properties of such a measure are crucial. The PI with his collaborators has made a great advance on this direction building the path to the solution of some old conjectures. 

 

This analysis was carried out through the careful study of Lyapunov exponents and its relation to the geometry of the measure along the associated Lyapunov directions. These Lyapunov directions are directions on the ambient space that reflect the precise expansion and contraction rates determined by the Lyapunov exponents. Through the Ledrappier-Young entropy formula one can relate the dimension of the measure along these Lyapunov directions, the Lyapunov exponents and the entropy of the systems. The PI with his collaborators has improved the understanding of the Ledrappier-Young  entropy formula in the multidimensional time setting which has applications for the analysis of systems with symmetries. 

 

T study of strong statistical properties of systems displaying some hyperbolicity has been carried out by the PI with his collaborators. The ultimate chaotic system is the coin flipping system. Systems presenting this type of chaoticity are called Bernoulli systems. Showing that systems are Bernoulli or not and developing techniques to do so is a very important task that has also been done in this project. Some systems in 4 dimensional space that have the Kolmogorov property but are not Bernoulli where built. Also equilibrium measures were studied in the context of partially hyperbolic systems and their Bernoullicity have been shown. 

 

While developing the mathematical tools the goal of the project has been as well to work with young mathematicians to help they growth in their careers. This includes graduate students, post docs and mathematicians in the beginning of their careers. The PI thinks of this as part of the broader impacts and has as well been very successful on this matter. Most of these young mathematicians are now quite independent and working on their own topics.
